Illinois Commission strikes big win for students who are transgender.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

The Illinois Human Rights Commission just issued a new and important finding. The Commission ruled that singling out transgender students and forcing them to change behind a privacy curtain violates Illinois law barring discrimination based on a person's gender identity.

This is the first time that the Commission has affirmed that the protections of the Illinois Human Rights Act require that transgender students be given not only use of a locker room but full and equal use of the locker rooms in their school. This finding reinforces what the law was passed to require — Illinoisans who are transgender must be offered the same opportunities to succeed as everyone else in this state.

The Commission's finding came in response to a complaint filed by a transgender student in School District 108, located in the Chicago suburbs. The Commission rejected the District's policy of requiring the student to dress behind a privacy curtain in the locker room because the "District's sole motivation" behind the policy "was rooted in the [student's] gender-related identity, transgender male." Although this finding applies to this school district alone, it sends a strong signal to all school districts in Illinois.

We will keep fighting across the state until all schools recognize their obligation to treat transgender students fairly by offering them the full and equal use of their facilities, like every other student.

Thanks for sticking with us,

ACLU of Illinois
